author: Interview by Nick McGrath
title: Shaun Ryder
text:
Ryder: ‘I had a few lost weekends in Amsterdam’ (Jo Hale/Getty) David Bowie’s Life on Mars was the soundtrack to my first holiday out of Britain in 1973, when I flew to Jersey, aged 11, with my nana and grandad. The year before that, my mum and dad had taken me and my brother Paul to this little village called Perranporth, in Cornwall. While they relaxed on the beach, we took advantage of the lack of ceiling mirrors in the local shops to stuff as many rings as we could into our pockets, to flog to our mates back at school.
I had the odd drunken teenage trip to Spain and a few lost weekends in Amsterdam, where the first thing we’d do was buy all the weed we could, before spending the next couple of days comatose in a coffee shop. We were way too stoned to get anywhere near Anne Frank’s house.
When the Mondays took off, we toured
